abstract: Study published in journal Current Biology finds male crickets linger near mate after copulating in order to protect females from predators. Study is conducted by researchers at the University of Exeter in England.
snippet: A recent study in the wild suggests that male crickets linger after mating to protect females from predation rather than to fend off rivals.
lead_paragraph: A recent study in the wild suggests that male crickets linger after mating to protect females from predation rather than to fend off rivals.

headline.main: Cricket Hovers After Sex to Ensure Mate’s Safety
